channel.title: Comments on: Procedure expects parameter error from SqlCommand
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.description: of course you should have said to your developer that he should use conn.Createcommand and cmd.Createparameter instead. But I'm sure you did.
item.content:encoded: of course you should have said to your developer that he should use conn.Createcommand and cmd.Createparameter instead. But I’m sure you did.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: Yup. What I was going at there...
item.content:encoded: Yup. What I was going at there…

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.description: If the CommandType is not specified, it defaults to CommandType.Text You should always explicitly specify a commandtype if using a stored procedure.
item.content:encoded: If the CommandType is not specified, it defaults to CommandType.Text You should always explicitly specify a commandtype if using a stored procedure.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Yeah that is also the reason that I don't use inline parameters like that
item.content:encoded: Yeah that is also the reason that I don’t use inline parameters like that

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: :) Yup. That email while I was driving home was about this one. Thanks again for eyeing that parm missing in there. I didn't see it even after looking at it for what seemed, forever
